description: From Middle English godsybbe, godsib (“a close friend or relation, a confidant; a godparent”), from Old English godsibb (“godparent, sponsor”), equivalent to god +‎ sib. Doublet of godsib.

entries.meaning: (countable) Someone who likes to talk about other people's private or personal business.
examples: Synonyms: busybody, gossipmonger, meddler, rumormonger; see also Thesaurus:gossiper
Be careful what you say to him: he’s a bit of a gossip.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Idle talk about someone’s private or personal matters, especially someone not present.
examples: Synonyms: dirt, hearsay, rumor, scandal, scuttlebutt; see also Thesaurus:rumor
According to the latest gossip, their relationship is on the rocks.
I have a juicy piece of gossip to share with you.
Synonyms: chat, chinwag, chit-chat, natter; see also Thesaurus:chatter

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A genre in contemporary media, usually focused on the personal affairs of celebrities.
(now only historical) A sponsor; a godfather or godmother; the godparent of a child.
(obsolete) Title used with the name of one's child's godparent or of a friend.

verbs.description: gossip (third-person singular simple present gossips, present participle gossiping or gossipping, simple past and past participle gossiped or gossipped)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To talk about someone else's private or personal business, especially in a manner that spreads the information.
examples: Synonyms: blab, dish the dirt, spill the tea, talk out of turn, tell tales out of school
Synonyms: chat, chatter, chew the fat, chinwag, natter, prattle, shoot the breeze

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To stand godfather to; to provide godparents for.
(obsolete) To enjoy oneself during festivities, to make merry.
